Message: This makes me so happy! Thanks for sharing :) Hope everyone's having awonderful summer.Best,AidaOn Tue, Jul 18, 2017 at 10:29 PM, Olivia Fales <ofales@hammer.ucla.edu>wrote:> I love this teacher. This was her third year visiting, I believe. Thanks> for sharing, Tara!>> Sent from my iPhone>> On Jul 18, 2017, at 1:19 PM, Tara Burns <tburns@hammer.ucla.edu> wrote:>> Hello everyone!>>>> Such a sweet email of gratitude below from a school group that visited the> Hammer this past March. Look at what you helped the students create!>>>>>> *From:* Lindsay Parker [mailto:lparker@jtdschool.org> <lparker@jtdschool.org>]> *Sent:* Tuesday, July 18, 2017 11:20 AM> *To:* Tara Burns <tburns@hammer.ucla.edu>> *Subject:* Thank you and coordinating for next year!>>>> Hi Tara,>>      I‰Ûªm sorry to be so tardy in sending you a thank you for our school> visit to the Hammer this past spring, but I wanted to make sure to do so> now! The spring just seemed to fly by into summer and before I knew it I> was sitting and planning next year‰Ûªs calendar with my colleagues. I know> it‰Ûªs a bit in advance, but we plan a year out and would like to visit again> next year on Thurs, March 22 if possible. I understand you may not be able> to schedule us that far in advance but thought I would relay this info to> you just in case :)>>      In the meantime, please let me tell you what a wonderful time all of> us had and how excited JTD Arts is to have such a fantastic place as the> Hammer welcome us as visitors. Thank you for all your help in coordinating> a seamless visit - the kids were still talking about how much they loved it> when we reflected back on our favorite parts of the year before breaking> for summer.>>      I‰Ûªve attached some photos of the Dubuffet-inspired piece my K-3> students created in connection to a unit we did on him because of our trip> to you. It was so successful it was just framed and placed in our boardroom> and I know that success is in large part to what the students saw and> learned during their trip to the Hammer.>>      Thank you again and I look forward to talking to you and visiting the> Hammer again soon.>>>> Best,>> Lindsay>>>> <image001.jpg><image002.jpg>>> ||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||>> Ms. Lindsay Parker>> The John Thomas Dye School>> Visual Arts Lead Teacher Grades K-3>> Co-Director of the ASC and Summer Programs>> (310) 476-2811 (ext. 2010)>> lparker@jtdschool.org>> ||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||>>>>>>>>>>>-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Mr. Samsoedien,Hello! This is Aida, the iXperience student from UCLA and grand niece ofMr. Ghazzali. I believe my Uncle Oli has contacted you regarding my visitto Cape Town; if you are not too busy, I would very much like to chat withyou and learn more about South Africa and your experience living here. OuriX classes are in the morning and afternoon, so if you are available in theevening, perhaps we can arrange a time to meet? I just arrived today andwill be here until August 19th.A little about me: I study Statistics and English at UCLA, and the iXcourses I'm taking are teaching me skills that I can use in data science.I'm interested in everything, but I tend to gravitate toward literature andart. I love talking to my uncle about history, and I hope to learn moreabout the history and culture in SA in order to better understand my placeas a temporary student/resident of Cape Town and, more generally, a youngperson in an ever-changing world! I also love reading, writing, and meetingnew people.Thank you, and I look forward to hearing from you!Best,Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | +01 (562) 673-1996

Hey Jarrett!I just wanted to ask whether you had some theme ideas or specific pieces ofart you wanted to talk about for the upcoming Art in Conversation tour thisSunday. Hi Professor Huehls,Here are the topic-question-stakes statements that I promised you a whileago. Apologies if they're coming in later than you would've liked them to;I wanted to get the *Very Short Introduction* reading in before I startedworking on it.I'm having a bit of trouble understanding the scope of each statementcomponent (scope within the book and scope in the research frameworksurrounding the book). My biggest concern is that my interests aren't veryresearchable, either because they're too vague or too large in scope giventhe time limits of this class. Anyway, here goes:1.    I am studying the expression of boredom in *The Pale King* because Iwant to find out what the relationship is between boredom and unfulfilleddesires to help my reader understand whether these desires are a reflectionof an American consumerist ethos.2.    I am studying the IRS workers‰Ûª boredom (or lack thereof) with theirjobs because I want to find out the causes and remedies of boredom in orderto help my reader better understand the shifting internal and externalcauses that gave rise to boredom as a human condition.3.    I am studying the expression of boredom in *The Pale King *because Iwant to understand its relationship to American culture as expressed in thenovel in order to help my reader understand how DFW historicizes thepresent through the depiction of boredom as a human condition.4.    I am studying the *The Pale King*‰Ûªs depiction of the IRS as a boringplace because I want to understand the features of the IRS that make itboring in order to help my reader understand the strained relationshipbetween humans and institutions.Thanks for your help,Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Professor Allmendinger,I hope this email finds you well. My name is Aida Ylanan, and I'm a thirdyear Statistics major and English minor who is looking to pursue a thesisher senior year. I'm writing you with a request for admission into theHonors program, primarily so I can join the research class currentlyunderway and complete a thesis next year. Given the timing of this request(as we're well into Spring quarter already) and my major, I understand thatthere are several factors discouraging me from pursuing this goal; however,I hope that in explaining my reasons for pursuing an Honors thesis, I mightencourage you to consider my admission into the program.My interest in completing a thesis formed at the nexus of my academic goalsand literary interests. A friend of mine (a thesis student who introducedme to the program this quarter) sparked my interest in the field of DigitalHumanities, and I'm hoping to combine my love of English and Statistics byexploring this discipline in graduate school. I was therefore hoping towrite a thesis so I would be a stronger candidate when applying for Englishgraduate programs. Given my lifelong love of literature, I had littletrouble coming up with a research topic that interested me: David FosterWallace and the way he explores the subject of tedium in *The Pale King*.I approached Professor Huehls with my proposal, and he agreed to work withme on my thesis. I also spoke with him about the Honors thesis program, andhe had no qualms about my joining the research seminar he is currentlyteaching, so long as there were no conflicts with the registrar and withthe English Honors program. I've spoken with Danielle in the counselingoffice and she recommended that I contact you with my thesis request.I understand there are alternatives to completing the Honors thesis, suchas the independent research class (English 199), but I think thatcompleting a thesis under the Honors program would better fit my academicgoals because of the skills I would develop in the research seminar thisquarter, along with the chance to work with Professor Huehls beforeformally starting the research project next year.Thank you for your time. If you have questions or concerns that you wouldrather discuss in person, then I am more than happy to meet at a time mostconvenient for you.Sincerely,Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

We sold out yet again! If you missedit last night, don't forget about the various discounts we offer studentsthroughout the season on our website: www.geffenplayhouse.org/college, wehope you'll join us.Wondering when the next College Night is? It's coming up on *May 18th*! Andit's a special one so make sure you read the whole email for all thedetails.Our next College Night is for the world premiere of *Actually* by AnnaZiegler. The play tells the story of Amber and Tom, finding their way asfreshmen at Princeton, spend a night together that alters the course oftheir lives. They agree on the drinking, they agree on the attraction, butconsent is foggy, and if unspoken, can it be called consent? A playwright *TheNew York Times* calls ‰ÛÏnewly (and justly) hot,‰Û Anna Ziegler investigatesgender and race politics, our crippling desire to fit in and the threesides to every story.The play stars Jerry MacKinnon (*Sleepy Hollow*) and Samantha Ressler (*Thisis the End*), and is brought to you *free of charge* and *free food* withthe generous support of The Biller Foundation. You read that right, thisone is free, and so is the food. That said, there are *only **40tickets* availablefor this College Night so get your tickets now! See below for our offercode and other information, with a link to get your tickets.College Night! *Actually* by Anna Ziegler.Thursday, May 18th. Pre-show party starts at *7pm* with free food TBA.Curtain at *8pm.*Offer code: ACTUALLYCOLLEGE for a free ticket. Limit of two per personwhile supplies last.Use the link to go straight to the ticket page and enter the code:https://tickets.geffenplayhouse.org/Online/mapSelect.aspStay tuned for a Facebook event page, we wanted to make sure we got theoffer out to you first. Tickets will sell out fast so do not miss thisopportunity!Finally, if you're passionate about the content of the play, we will beholding a special panel event, Raising the Curtain, hosted by KPCC's JohnHorn with a UCLA student panelist. The event is free and open to thepublic, RSVP below:http://www.geffenplayhouse.org/more_info.php?show_id=270As always, its a pleasure having you at the Geffen Playhouse and we hopeyou'll join us for this urgently relevant play. You are a valued part ofthe Playhouse's community.*Quinn Francis*Outreach AssistantThe Geffen Playhouse-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hi Jordan,I have a quick question about the narrative structure of *GreatExpectations. *Would you consider the novel to have a frame narrative? Asin, *GE*'s plot (of all that happens to Pip) is nestled within the factthat present (and therefore a different version of) Pip is retelling thestory.I curious about what term to use because I'm close reading Vol III ChapterXI, in which Magwitch's backstory is revealed to Pip (and the reader) underthe guise of Herbert taking care of Pip's burn wounds. I'm reallyinterested in this one story being contained within another, but I'm notsure what to call it.Thanks!AidaDiscussion 1F-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hi Zoe,Here are some replies I would make if I heard a microaggression during atour conversation:   - (engage in dialogue) Why do you believe what you said to be true?   - (more direct response) I don't think that kind of language helps move   the conversation forward and would appreciate it if you refrained from   saying that.I found myself having trouble writing a single response to microaggressionssince, as we said, they come in various forms and with different intents. Ifound the most practical approach, for me, was to respond to the prompt bya) writing multiple responses that b) approached the microaggression fromdifferent angles. I'll keep a general statement (like the one you wrote) inmy back pocket, though: if the conversation with the aggressor were toderail into something more confrontational, then I think having a short,pithy summary of our Hammer values would end the ordeal in a respectfulway.Best,Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Statistics B.S. | English Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

It's abit of a departure, but I'm actually aiming for a career in data science;my dream is to work as a data analyst in a publishing company (where my momprobably got the magazine idea from), where I can do something analyticalin a creatively-motivated environment.That being said, any internship opportunities from your company in oraround the field of data science would be much appreciated! Unfortunately, I don't have any information about API perception of Lieuafter he switched sides. I was hesitant to ask both interviewees abouttheir perceptions of API political opinions (both went out of their way toappear neutral and hesitated upon any questions remotely opinionated), andboth don't read ethnic newspapers since those are written in Mandarin.I'll make it a point to write about ethnic media then. Also, would it be aproblem if I sent over my final paper to Pamela Hung of TACL? She'd like toread it.And yes, feel free to send the documents to Axel!AidaOn Thu, Mar 23, 2017 at 11:09 PM, JOHN ZALLER <zaller@ucla.edu> wrote:> These documents are very helpful. Hi Amy,Here is the introductory letter (pasted below) that I'd like to send to Mr.Wong. If it's not clear enough then I would be happy to rewrite it. Thankyou!Aida Ylanan***Dear Mr. Wong,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing your perception of the relationship between AAPIgovernment officials and their AAPI constituents.I'm interested in exploring the sorts of issues that are important to theAAPI community, and the way that elected officials from the AAPI community,needing to represent a diverse constituency, might deal with them. Somequestions I want to explore: What are the issues important to AAPI folks?What organizations bring these issues to the table? What are therelationships like between grassroots organizations and AAPI governmentofficials? Are there differences between the way government officials talkto certain ethnic groups in the AAPI community as opposed to, say, the AAPIcommunity as a whole? His or her constituency as a whole? His or her partyas a whole?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it to no more than 30minutes.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above. Becauseof the nature of the class, many of the questions from above will involvethe nomination and election of AAPI individuals to Congress.  The professorin the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominations and I needto mention that he might use information from student papers like mine inhis book.  However, he would not use the names of any of the students‰Ûªsources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.Thank you for your time! I look forward to hearing from you!Aida Ylanan

Hi Professor Zaller,I recently got off the phone with Amy Watanabe, the Vice President of theWest-LA chapter of Japanese American Citizens League. She passed along thecontact information of her colleague, Thomas Wong, who is president of theBoard of Directors of the San Gabriel Valley Municipal Water District. He'sworked with Betty Yee, CA State Controller, and has experience bridging thegap between AAPI organizations and elected officials.Amy requested that I write up a more informative email about what I hope tolearn from him, so that he gets a better idea of the goals of the interviewand we don't have to waste as much time establishing context. The focus ofmy research is becoming more precise with the more information that Ireceive from these interviews and other Internet research, so I'm stilltrying to find the words to describe what exactly I'm looking for. I'mhoping that you could help me craft these goals in a way that makes sense.The draft of the letter to Mr. Wong is below.Thank you! I'll see you tomorrow.Aida***Dear Mr. Wong,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing your perception of the relationship between AAPIgovernment officials and their AAPI constituents.I'm interested in exploring the sorts of issues that are important to theAAPI community, and the way that AAPI politicians, having to govern adiverse constituency, might deal with them. Some questions I want toexplore: What are the issues important to AAPI folks? What organizationsbring these issues to the table? What are the relationships like betweengrassroots organizations and AAPI government officials? Are theredifferences between the way government officials talk to certain ethnicgroups in the AAPI community as opposed to, say, the AAPI community as awhole? His or her constituency as a whole? His or her party as a whole?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.Thank you for your time! I look forward to hearing from you.-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Ms. Hung,Hello! I know that Mr. Chou has linked us in a previous email, but I wantedto take some time to formally introduce myself and say a little bit aboutthe research I'm doing.I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing your organization‰Ûªs involvement (or possiblynon-involvement) in politics.Some questions I hope to answer are: What political issues are important tothe AAPI community? How do community organizations respond to these issues?What are some other organizations that have a stake in these issues andwhy?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.Thank you for your time! I look forward to hearing from you.Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Ms. Watanabe,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing APALF's involvement in politics. I spoke withMr. Floyd Mori of APAICS recently, and he recommended you as someone Icould contact.Some questions I hope to answer are: What political issues are important tothe AAPI community? How do community organizations respond to these issues?What are some other organizations that have a stake in these issues andwhy?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.Thank you!Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Mr. Yin,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing your organization‰Ûªs involvement in politics. Ispoke with Mr. Floyd Mori of APAICS recently, and he recommended you assomeone I could contact.Some questions I hope to answer are: What political issues are important tothe AAPI community? How do community organizations respond to these issues?What are some other organizations that have a stake in these issues andwhy?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.Thank you!Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

How do community organizations respond to these issues?What are some other organizations that have a stake in these issues andwhy?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Hi Professor Zaller,Here's my draft of the revised interview requests. I added a bit more tothe original one; I wanted to set some expectations about the sorts ofanswers I'm looking for in the interview. The letter is below:Dear _____,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement of AsianAmericans and Pacific Islanders in electoral politics in the U.S.  It ishard to learn about this subject from the Internet or other public sourcesof information, so I am writing you in the hope that you will give me ashort interview describing your organization‰Ûªs involvement (or quitepossibly non-involvement) in politics.  I am also interested in yourperception of other AAPI groups that may or may not be involved inpolitics.Some questions I hope to answer are: What political issues are important tothe AAPI community? How do community organizations respond to these issues?What are some other organizations that have a stake in these issues andwhy?If you grant me an interview, I promise to keep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources, just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here, especially as an AAPI studentwith a burgeoning interest in U.S. politics.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation where I could meet you. Given my class schedule, the best timesfor me would be Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday mornings, or any evening.-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Ms. Lu,Thank you for your response. I appreciate your clarification, but I hopethat we can still have a short conversation. I am at an early stage of myresearch in which I am just trying to talk to people in the Taiwanese andChinese API community around Los Angeles to get a sense of how thecommunity works and what it cares about. Any help you can give wouldbe greatly appreciated.Thank you for your time and understanding.Sincerely,Aida YlananOn Mon, Feb 27, 2017 at 5:43 PM, TAF Marketing <tafmarketing@tafworld.org>wrote:> Aida,>> Thank you for your inquiry. Hi Professor Zaller,Here's my draft of the letter I'm planning to send to organizations whodeclined an interview after citing charitable organization status. Theletter will go to the Taiwanese American Foundation, as we talked aboutearlier today, and to Asian Americans Advancing Justice<http://www.advancingjustice-la.org/>, who had this bit of usefulinformation:"Unfortunately, we aren't able to help as we are a charitable nonprofitorganization and cannot (and do not) take positions on candidates orparties."Another update: I got a response from the Executive Vice President of TaiwaneseAmerican Professionals - Los Angeles <http://www.tap-la.org/>, Mr. TonyChou, who agreed to set up an interview for this Thursday. I'll think of afew questions to ask him and send them in another email, so this onedoesn't get too long.The drafted email is below:Dear ____,Thank you for your response. I appreciate your clarification, though I hopethat we can still remain in contact. I am at an early stage of my research,so I am just trying to talk to people in the Taiwanese and Chinese APIcommunity around Los Angeles about topics that do not necessarily relate topolitics. I would not ask you about your own activities but about theactivities of other Taiwanese and Chinese API groups, in order to get ageneral sense of how both communities are organized in the area. Any helpwould be greatly appreciated.Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Here are the questions I have so far:What does the Asian Pacific American Institute for Congressional Studiesdo? *How does the work of the Leadership Network differ from the mainorganization?*Is the work of APAICS concentrated mostly at the governmental level, thegrassroots level, somewhere in between, or does the organization devote itstime equally to all levels of political involvement? What is the nature ofthe work done at each level?How often does APAICS involve itself with API community organizations?Taiwanese or Chinese API groups?Does APAICS have representatives outside of Washington D.C.?My research project looks at open seat nominations to the House in the2013-14 election cycle, one of which was won by Ted Lieu in California‰Ûªs33rd district, or the district that UCLA is in. Does the APAICS have arelationship with Lieu, either while he was campaigning to be aRepresentative or after he entered the House?What are some other organizations APAICS has worked with?Here are some other questions I have about my project that I'm hoping todiscuss with you tomorrow:   - Is it appropriate to try and contact someone on Lieu's team to ask if   the campaign was involved with Taiwanese or Chinese API groups?   - Can I follow up unanswered emails with a phone call?   - The Taiwanese American Foundation (TAF) foundation cited this response   in its decline to interview: "Due to our 501c3 status, we are unable to be   involved in politics." Is it worth explaining that no political information   necessarily needs to be involved, or should I just respect their polite   decline?See you tomorrow,AidaOn Mon, Feb 27, 2017 at 12:17 PM, JOHN ZALLER <zaller@ucla.edu> wrote:> It might be useful for you to write out your list of questions and send it> ahead to me.>> On Mon, Feb 27, 2017 at 12:05 PM, AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu> > wrote:>>> That sounds great. To whom it may concern,I am a junior at UCLA doing a research paper on the involvement ofTaiwanese Americans and Chinese Americans in electoral politics in theU.S.  It is hard to learn about this subject from the Internet or otherpublic sources of information, so I am writing you in the hope that youwill give me a short interview describing your organization‰Ûªs involvement(or possibly non-involvement) in politics.  I am also interested in yourperception of other Taiwanese and Chinese American groups that may or maynot be involved in politics.  If you grant me an interview, I promise tokeep it short ‰ÛÒ probably 10 to 15 minutes and certainly no more than 30.I am doing my research paper for a class on party nominations for the Houseof Representatives. Each student in the class picked a topic on some aspectof party politics and the topic I chose is the one mentioned above.  Theprofessor in the class, John Zaller, is doing a book on party nominationsand I need to mention that he might use information from student paperslike mine in his book.  However, he would not use the names of any of thestudents‰Ûª sources -- just the information they provide.As you know, research is a big deal at UCLA and I am really enjoying myinvolvement in a real research project here.  If you are willing to grantme an interview to help with my research, please suggest a time andlocation (if your organization has representatives in the LA area) where Icould meet you. We can also arrange a phone interview if that would workbetter for you; my phone number is listed in my signature below. Given myclass schedule, the best times for me would be Tuesday, Thursday, andFriday mornings, or any evening.Thank you!Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hey! I like your idea about looking at a couple of paintings at once,especially if each group we have is large. An idea I have is to discuss, atthe beginning, certain feature of Dubuffet's work (drawing style, imprintprocess, artistic themes, etc); then the guide can have people break offinto pairs/groups, have different pairs look at different pieces, and thenhave pairs report how the style/process/theme is evoked in each art piece.If groups were smaller, though, I wouldn't mind sticking to one piece pertalking point. There's definitely a lot to unpack as far as history/arttheory/etc go hahahaOn Wed, Feb 1, 2017 at 3:20 PM, Jarrett Lampley <jarrettlampley@gmail.com>wrote:> Hi everyone!>> I just walked through Dubuffet and thought it may be interesting to talk> about his pieces in groups. Hey!I really like the ideas that DJ threw around: resistance to the artworld/traditional artistic forms with Dubuffet, resistance to Americancolonialism with Durham. In these resistances, I also see a mutual desireto bring the unconventionally artistic into a more artistic light. Dubuffetdrew inspiration from children's drawings and psychiatric patients (puttingaside what he learned in art school) and Durham took second hand items andrepurposed them into art.Those are the only ideas that immediately come to mind that link the two.Would love to hear more ideas or further develop this one!On Mon, Jan 30, 2017 at 10:06 AM, Jarrett Lampley <jarrettlampley@gmail.com>wrote:> Hi you two!>> Just wanted to let you know that I talked to the coordinator of the law> event coming this Thursday, and she requested that we tour Jimmie Durham> and Dubuffet. ---------- Forwarded message ----------From: Diana Gilmore <di.m.gilmore@gmail.com>Date: Tue, Jan 3, 2017 at 10:42 PMSubject: Re: iXperience Questions | c/o 2017To: AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>Hi Aida,So exciting that you were admitted to iXperience! It was truly the mostrewarding summer experience I could have ever asked for.I'm currently out of the country traveling in India, and don't have accessto my exact charges from the trip, however I would say their estimates arerelatively accurate.The rand is relatively weak to the dollar so everything was extremely cheapcompared to prices in America. So in terms of food/drink you'll only spendabout 10-15 dollars a day (60 days at $10 a day... $600 for the trip) ifyou're eating out, and breakfast is provided I believe (if it's the same aslast year). There is always the option of buying from the grocery store aswell, which is even more inexpensive. That being said, there are TONS ofactivities to do in Cape Town (markets, boat rides, tours to Cape Point,other sites to see etc) and they do cost money. I would suggest researchingsome of those activities to see if you'd be interested in doing them andthen plan accordingly. I can assure you those aren't too expensive as well.Regarding flights, if you book early there are definitely inexpensiveflights, so I would research that as soon as possible to get quotes.Let me know if you have any other specific questions, I'd love to help!Best,DianaOn Sun, Jan 1, 2017 at 2:08 AM AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>wrote:> Hi Diana!>> My name is Aida, and I was just admitted to iXperience's Class of 2017! Hi Zoe,Thanks so much for the guidance and the links! They were all great; Iespecially liked yours, along with Gwynn's, Elena's and Maddie's. I lovedthat these articles offered helpful facts and other pieces of informationto supplement the observations made while working at the Hammer. I washoping to do something similar, because I'm really interested insynthesizing all of the research I've been doing for our currentinstallations with some of the experiences I've had during my Art inConversation tours here -- basically, a more developed summary of thethemes I've previously explored with museum goers. Something along thelines of...- The Space Around Us: How Simone Leigh and Nicolas Party play withdimension: size and scope can dramatically affect the way a viewerinteracts with a piece of art, as Leigh and Party have demonstrated. Howdid museum goers feel when asked about this phenomenon? Hayk and Aidareport.- On Simone Leigh, Marwa Arsanios and the Nexus of Art and PoliticalAwareness: world events have long galvanized the politically aware, andartists often use their medium to voice their reactions. What did Leigh andArsanios have to say about the politics that affected them? Maddy and Aidaexplore this question one afternoon.[catchier, more succinct titles forthcoming]In writing these blog posts, I was also hoping to receive suggestions aboutthe way I critically think about art. Do these align with the sort ofcontent the Hammer Blog pursues? They're a bit more thematicallygoal-oriented than other, more observational posts I've seen.Thanks again -- I hope your time at the Hammer has been wonderful thus far!Warmly,AidaOn Tue, Nov 29, 2016 at 11:04 AM, Zoe Silverman <zsilverman@hammer.ucla.edu>wrote:> Hi Aida,>>>> Thanks for getting in touch ‰ÛÒ  I think it‰Ûªs awesome that students now have> the opportunity to contribute to the  Hammer Blog. Dear Sarita,I'm so sorry for my delayed response. I moved into an apartment for thefirst time, so the past couple of weeks has been a logistical learningprocess for me and my parents. Thank you for your patience!Here's a brief reflection of my time at CA+T:*What were your expectations of the internship? Were these expectationsfulfilled or did they change in either a negative or positive way?*Because this was my first experience getting strongly involved with an nonprofit, much less one centered around the arts, I didn't have very manyexpectations coming into the internship. I thought I would participate indiscussions about art, culture, philosophy, and other similar topics (whichI really enjoyed discussing with Clare in our weekly meetings) andparticipate in the curation of a CA+T virtual exhibit/get a sneak previewof what we were going to feature (which I wasn't able to do so much). Ialso anticipated being more involved in the grant-writing process, butbecause I came at a time when we review past grant submissions more than wewrite new ones, I understand that my role in the grant process had tochange a bit.*What would you recommend strongly about this internship to other potentialor future interns?*A really valuable experience I took away from this internship was aboutlogistics. I really appreciate my time working with Clare and how shenavigated me through non profits' relationship with grant writing. Ilearned about the level of organization/planning that non profits must havewhen applying for funding. I read the kind of language one has to use whenapplying for grants, and I realized that both clarity and specificitymatter when communicating organizational goals/mission statements.Another important part of this internship was the opportunity to work withpeople who share the passion for art and representation that I do. Havingthe ability to collaborate with coworkers who are united by a passion forart and the mission to give more people access to it was extremelyinspiring and encouraging!*What would you suggest that CA+T changes about our internship approach?*I would've benefited from a more formalized internship with CA+T. A lot ofmy assignments felt improvised, though I understand that there are limitsto the internship program because of our small staff, irregular grantschedule, and the fact that we operate almost entirely remotely. I alsothink a small orientation would have been nice, to learn more about CA+T'shistory and mission statement from the people who wrote it.I wanted to thank you again for this chance to learn and grow with CA+T!I've come away from this experience with a greater appreciation for allthat the organization stands for, and I look forward to bringing thesevalues with me into all my future endeavors.Warmly,Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Oysim,Thank you again for your quick response regarding our upcoming 16 Days ofActivism project. I am writing to inform you that the angle for ourproposal has changed slightly -- for the presentation in which we hope youcould speak, we have decided to approach the multi-stakeholder platformmore from the experience of the social worker. We hope to inform the publicof what to expect from each stakeholder, i.e. what the police can do foryou, when to consult a welfare officer, and the like. We are also thinkingof delving into the legal aspect of the DV reporting process, like talkingabout the differences between civil and criminal court and when each courtis involved. We hope that you will be able to lend us your time andknowledge for this legal section of the presentation.Again, the discussion will be on 23 November at 2 Jalan Hang Kasturi KualaLumpur 50050. Heang Lee (cc'ed in this email) and I would be happy toanswer any questions you might have. We look forward to hearing from you!Thank you,Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hey Clare,How are you? What is CA+T up to nowadays?Thank you again for the reading material; they've made me more cognizant ofmy roles and responsibilities as a person working abroad without actuallyliving here. Barbie Savior was my favorite! So weird how social mediasomehow brought a layer of vanity into the mess that voluntourism alreadyis. I'm thankful that the organization I work for doesn't succumb to thisweird 21st century voluntourism trend. I think the fact that it is aMalaysian-born organization that emphasizes learning and understandingamong its interns makes the experience feel a lot less disingenuous.It's hard to summarize how much interning abroad has helped me understandmyself and the rest of the world (cliche, I know) but I think one of themost important takeaways was seeing empowered SE Asian women making acareer out of their passion for human rights. I remember talking to youbefore about what a privilege it is to be surrounded by people doing workthey genuinely care about; it's truly inspiring to see people doing what Iwant to do *and* who actually look like me. I'd never really had any SEAsian woman role models in the legal field before now, so realizing howmany Filipina lawyers there are in this world helped me to see the glass-and bamboo-ceilings (some of them self-imposed) that discouraged me fromconsidering law. It meant a lot to see the world from the other side ofacademia, hahaAside from that, I had another thing I wanted to ask you about -- do youknow when Bovey Lee's interview will be published? I remember she requestedthat we send it over to her so she can post a link on her own website, too.Just didn't want to leave her hanging.Thank you! I look forward to hearing from you again :)Warmly,Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hey Natasha,I just have a quick clarification that needs to be made regarding Annex 3(Online VAW) of the DVA Amendment Supplemental Info doc.The document you forwarded to me about online VAW included this suggestionas an amendment to the DVA:*"For stalking to be criminalized as per the Joint Action Group for GenderEquality‰Ûªs proposed amendment to the DVA, inclusive of stalking through theuse of ICT."*I just wanted to double check that stalking is currently not included inthe DVA act or in its 2012 amendment? And that the current set ofamendments we are proposing in 2016 would be to state stalking moreexplicitly as an offense under the DVA?Is stalking not considered the act of "willfully or knowingly placing, orattempting to place, the victim in fear of physical injury" or "causingmischief or destruction or damage to property with intent to cause, orknowing that it is likely to cause distress or annoyance to the victim, bya person against (i) his or her spouse" (DVA Part I Section 2)?I'm sorry if this is a bit pedantic. I'm as curious about this as I amintent on making this a thorough report.Thank you!Aida-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

We are excited to have you on board, and> it's nice to see a fellow UC'er :) (I'm Berkeley '07)>> I will actually be on leave next week, but I think it might be helpful for> you to get started with going through a few documents that will provide> helpful context and background for the work we do in the Advocacy team.>> Most likely, one of the main things you'll be helping to work on is a> report of our Annual Statistics. Last year, we presented this report in the> form of a case-study document, but this year we are likely going to present> the information in a more narrative form, though we are still trying to> decide what 'angle' to take. When you come in next Monday, it will be> helpful for you to first go through last year's report, which is called the> "Working Together Document" so you can get familiarized with what kind of> data we collect, and also understand some of the issues that arise with> domestic violence cases. Kelvin (cc'd here) will be able to give you a copy> of that.>> I'll also forward you an email of a Powerpoint presentation that you can> take a look at, which contains our annual statistics from 2015, which would> be what the report is covering.>> Finally, I'll also send you a separate email with some materials related> to CEDAW, the Convention on Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination> Against Women. CEDAW is at the core of most of the work that we do, so it'd> be good for you to familiarize yourself with it a bit.>> Hopefully this isn't too much info all at once! I just wanted to throw out> a couple things that you can start with next week to get acquainted. Since> next week is a short week with the Raya holidays, I think you can probably> focus more on reading up on stuff as preparation for actual assignments.> Does this sound okay to you?>> Thanks and look forward to meeting you soon,> Natasha>>>> On Sun, Jun 26, 2016 at 5:39 AM, AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>> wrote:>>> Hi Natasha,>>>> My name is Aida, and I'm an incoming WAO intern who'll begin work July>> 4th. Hi Clare,Here's the follow up question and answers (original and revised) about xuanpaper:AY: Do you think the rich archival history of your medium, Chinese xuanpaper, impacts the meaning of your contemporary work? If it does, then howso?BL: The rich archival history of xuan paper makes the record andpreservation of the rich cultural expressions possible. The archivalquality of xuan paper is one of the reasons why I am able to do what I'vebeen doing, which is to give nod to traditional art and paper cutting,while carrying it forward to the 21st century in ways it has not been donebefore. I think using xuan paper, my work as it exists in time and space,becomes part of that artistic succession.BL (revised): The rich archival history of xuan paper makes the record andpreservation of the rich cultural expressions possible. The archivalquality of xuan paper is one of the reasons why I am able to do what I'vebeen doing: [giving a] nod to traditional art and paper cutting whilecarrying it forward to the 21st century in ways it has not been donebefore. I think [by] using xuan paper, my work as it exists in time andspace becomes part of that artistic succession.I was able to send over the executed LLA too. What are the next steps forthe interview?Thanks!Best,On Thu, Jun 16, 2016 at 10:00 AM, AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>wrote:> Hey Clare,>> Great revisions -- the interview reads a lot more smoothly now! Dear Ms. Navarroza,Hello! My name is Aida Ylanan, and I'm a second year Political Science andStatistics student at UCLA. I currently work as an intern with the Centerfor Art and Thought, and we're developing a series of interviews withartists who have contributed to any of CA+T's exhibitions throughout theyears. I was revisiting our *Sea, Land, Air* exhibition when your workcaught my eye. Sarita See, the Executive Director of CA+T, and mysupervisor Clare Counihan (copied in this email) suggested your work wouldmake an excellent topic for an interview.CA+T interviews artists to learn more about their background, theinspirations for their work, and what they hope to convey through theirpieces. Sample interviews can be found here<http://www.centerforartandthought.org/cat-interview-johanna-poethig> andhere <http://centerforartandthought.org/cat-interviews-laura-swanson>. Allarticles are run by the artist before their publication.Most interviews are conducted via email, but we would be delighted toconduct a Skype or telephone interview as well -- whichever you prefer. Theinterview is more casual than formal, and we would like to learn more aboutyour photography techniques and artistic process.What drew me into your work was your choice of artistic subject. Your *PerhapsIt Was Possibly Because *series features arguably banal subjects, but notin the negative sense of the word; rather, each tableau seems to extractmeaning from a scene otherwise overlooked because of its normalcy. I'd loveto talk more with you about what you see in the world through your cameralens, and perhaps I could learn a thing or two about how to see my dailyroutine in a new light.Thank you for your time, and thank you for your thoughtful contributions toCA+T. I look forward to seeing more of your art in the future!Warmly,Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hi Teo,My name is Aida Ylanan, and I was in your History 20 class last fallquarter 2015! I just wanted to write and say that I finally finished thecopy of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, and it is now one of my favoritebooks of all time (and Austen now one of my favorite authors ever)!!!You're right -- the movies don't do the book justice, and the richness ofAusten's writing makes the story all the more meaningful. Elizabeth'srelationship with her father reminded me of my own relationship with mydad. I hope to be more like Lizzy as I grow older -- independent, witty,responsible, and willing to acknowledge her shortcomings. Thank you forintroducing me to another literary role model.   I'll be starting my copyof Emma tonight!I also wanted to thank you for enriching my experience at UCLA. I miss Hist20 a lot, and I carry the lessons I learned from that class with mewhenever I visit the museum or revisit some of the texts we looked at inclass. Our discussions in office hours meant a lot to me and reminded mehow much I love to study history. I hope you are well and wish you a happyretirement!Warmly,Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Dear Ms. Lee,Hello! My name is Aida Ylanan, and I'm a second year Political Sciencestudent at UCLA. I currently work as an intern with the Center for Art andThought, and we're developing a series of interviews with artists who havecontributed to any of CA+T's exhibitions throughout the years. I wasrevisiting our *Racecraft* exhibition when your work caught my eye. SaritaSee, the Executive Director of CA+T, and my supervisor Clare Counihan(copied in this email) suggested your work would make an excellent topicfor an interview.CA+T interviews artists to learn more about their background, theinspirations for their work, and what they hope to convey through theirpieces. Sample interviews can be found here<http://www.centerforartandthought.org/cat-interview-johanna-poethig> andhere <http://centerforartandthought.org/cat-interviews-laura-swanson>. Allarticles are run by the artist before their publication.Most interviews are conducted via email, but because CA+T operates out ofthe Los Angeles area, our team is enthusiastic about the idea of an instudio interview! With your permission, we could arrange an interview atyour studio during a time/date most convenient for you. The interview wouldconsist of a photo-documented tour, along with some questions asked duringand after the tour. Our conversation is intended to be more casual thanformal, and any audio recording would be used to transcribe the interviewlater on. The interview and corresponding photos would be published onlywith your final approval. If you would prefer to hold an interview overemail instead, then CA+T would be happy to continue to correspond with youdigitally!What drew me into your work was how incredibly delicate and intricate eachpiece is. The nature of your medium alone adds unique thematic elementsthat contribute to the meaning of each work, and I'd love to explore thesethemes with you in person. I'm also very much interested in what inspiredyou to become an artist, where your inspiration comes from for particularpieces, and what sorts of stories you aim to tell in your art.Thank you for your time, and thank you for your spellbinding contributionsto CA+T. I look forward to seeing more of your art in the future!Warmly,Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*Intern | Center for Art and Thought | http://centerforartandthought.org/University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hello!My name is Aida Ylanan, and I'm writing in hopes of receiving some guidancefrom you about gender studies and its related research. I have anopportunity this July to intern at the Women's Aid Organisation, an NGOlocated in Malaysia (http://www.wao.org.my). The organization is currentlyrunning campaigns to empower survivors of Sex and Gender-Based Violence,primarily through law reform, public education, case advocacy, andgovernment agency engagement. I've been given the opportunity to help outwith these campaigns and even conduct research if I'm interested in doingso.However, I have no formal/academic experience regarding gender studies (myknowledge comes from reading blogs and articles in my free time), and I washoping to better prepare myself for the sort of environment I'll besubmerged in soon. Would you be available to meet at any time, perhapsduring your office hours, to talk more about the sort of preparation Iwould need for an environment  like this, and how I can make the most ofthis opportunity? A list of recommended readings would be very muchappreciated as well.Thank you for your time.Sincerely,-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hi Tatay,Here's the message that Lainey passed on to me, regarding housing:"On the question on housing, no we do not have housing provided forinterns. Interns typically look for their own housing--I found my placeonline near the office a couple of days before I started with WAO lastyear! It is a shared accommodation in an apartment with other tenantsrenting other rooms. There are AirBnB options that seem really affordabletoo, especially since you're only here for a month. We're located near AsiaJaya LRT station, in Section 14 Petaling Jaya, also close to Jaya ShoppingCentre and the Digital Mall. Apartments nearby include Millennium Square,Menara Jaya, and Centrestage. There is also the option of renting a room ina house."The WAO Office's address is Jalan Sultan 46760 Petaling Jaya Selangor,Malaysia (just typing in Womens Aid Organisation into Google Maps willreturn the correct location).Searching Petaling Jaya Selangor Malaysia into airbnb.com gave me the listof nearby rooms/apts available for rent.I'll ask Lainey if there are any other interns from the U.S. coming thissummer. Let me know if there is any other information you'd like me to ask.Thank you! Love you!-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

I'll be looking through the course catalog forprogramming classes at LBCC this week and doing some reading in themeantime! Knowing what I have to do to achieve my goals is one of the bestfeelings ever; thanks for helping me realize that.I'm sure I'll need your help, guidance, and motivation as I move alongthrough these courses, so I'll be sure to stay in touch. As a fellowFilipina Bruin, I'll be sure to make you and the rest of PAA proud!Have a wonderful week.Best,On Fri, Apr 1, 2016 at 9:55 PM, Matthew David <matt.david@hulu.com> wrote:> Hi Aida!>> It was great speaking to you, too. Hopefully I can be of some help. I'm> glad someone is delving even a little bit into my field. There's always> talk of a lack of people in STEM focuses, especially with programming, but> the number of people doing it (especially with Filipinos) hasn't seen much> growth at all.>> I would say a programming bootcamp is overboard. They are usually meant to> prepare you for a career in web development in a startup environment right> out of the course. Because of that, they also tend to cost a lot. I see> prices for $3k for part time, >$10k for full time (yeesh).>> Summer courses would definitely be a good idea. I think that learning with> a teacher in an interactive environment is a lot better than online, since> you get real feedback.>> I spent a little time looking up resources:>>    - Python has some good resources online:>       - I highly recommend the official Python tutorial. It may be very>       verbose, and the setup/install process is daunting, but it doesn't skip>       anything. I'm down to help walk you through things, cuz getting set up is>       always the toughest part. If anything, the official site is a>       *really* good reference, no matter where you're learning from.>          - https://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/>       - This site looks pretty good, too. It runs everything in the>       browser, so it doesn't require you to install Python. It doesn't have all>       the detail as the official site so it skips some important things, but it>       lets you touch the basics more quickly. I'd still recommend doing the>       official Python tutorial after this, though.>          - http://www.learnpython.org/>       - SQL is harder to get started with. SQL is a general query>    language run on a lot of different databases (MySQL being the most>    popular). They can be a huge pain to get running on your computer, too.>       - Khan Academy has a SQL tutorial that does a decent job of>       explaining how to work on an existing database>          - https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-programming/sql>       - Relational database design (what any SQL database is) can be>       learned separately. It's less about programming and more about>       understanding how the data you're working with relates to one another. I>       wouldn't say it's entirely necessary, but knowing how/why a database is set>       up helps you understand how you should be querying it. Vice versa, you'll>       understand how a database can be set up based on the type of queries you>       expect to run on it.>          - This is a concise overview, but may be too theoretical to make>          sense with its basic example:>          http://www.ntu.edu.sg/home/ehchua/programming/sql/relational_database_design.html>> If you want to spend some money to get real legit books, the O'Reilly> series is probably the most popular set of books out there, too, though I> don't own them myself. They're also popular for having random pictures of> animals on the covers. Because of course a Python book has a picture of a> mouse on it:>>    - Python:>    http://www.amazon.com/Learning-Python-5th-Mark-Lutz/dp/1449355730/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1459570383&sr=8-2&keywords=o+reilly+python>    - Learning SQL:>    http://www.amazon.com/Learning-SQL-Alan-Beaulieu/dp/0596520832/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1459570409&sr=8-6&keywords=o+reilly+sql>> Anyways, have a good night and a good weekend! Let me know if you have any> questions, guidance or motivation!>> - Matt David>> From: AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>> Date: Thursday, March 31, 2016 at 6:50 PM> To: Matt David <matt.david@hulu.com>> Subject: PAA Networking Event Follow-Up>> Hi Matt,>> It was great getting to speak with you at yesterday's Pilipino Alumni> Association Networking Night! Hello!My name is Aida Ylanan, and I'm a second year who's very much interested inapplying to the Social Thought minor. I have a few questions about it, andif it would be much easier for me to come into your office and talk to youabout it, I'd be happy to do that as well!My interest in the minor stemmed from my burgeoning interest in thephilosophical texts we read in Political Science 10. I wish to read moreabout modern philosophy and, more specifically, to use this interest inbettering my critical reading and writing skills.I'm a bit hesitant to apply to the major, however, because I currently haveno plans to pursue Political Science in graduate school. Instead, I amconsidering law school. Is the Social Thought minor developed specificallyfor those planning to get post-graduate humanities degrees in mind? Is itokay to participate in the minor purely out of interest?Thank you!-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Is this something I should apply to?---------- Forwarded message ----------From: James Bondurant <bonduran@polisci.ucla.edu>Date: Fri, Mar 4, 2016 at 10:27 AMSubject: [POLISCI-JUNIORS] $ INTERNSHIP: Summer in San Francisco! Full-Timewith Williams-Sonoma - Apply by March 11To: POLISCI-JUNIORS@lists.sscnet.ucla.edu*From:* Career Center Internships [mailto:Internships@career.ucla.edu]*Sent:* Thursday, March 03, 2016 6:51 PM*To:* Career Center Internships <Internships@career.ucla.edu>*Subject:* Summer in San Francisco! Full-Time Paid Internship withWilliams-Sonoma - Apply by March 11Please share this message with all UCLA Bruins who are seeking a full-timepaid internship in Public Relations, Retail Management, Finance, Web Designor one of many other fields.  Williams-Sonoma is now hiring summer internsfor their San Francisco Corporate Office.UCLA juniors from all majors are encouraged to apply on BruinView (beforethe March 11 deadline) at career.ucla.edu.  Log into BruinView, click‰Û÷Jobs‰Ûª and keyword search Job ID number 912279 to learn more and submityour resume!Here is additional information from the Williams-Sonoma posting onBruinView.  Best wishes to all Bruins who apply!-------------------------------------------------------------OUR COMPANYWilliams-Sonoma, Inc. is a multi-channel specialty retailer of homefurnishings and gourmet cookware prided for ‰ÛÏenhancing the quality of lifeat home.‰Û We offer high-quality, stylish products for every room in thehouse ‰ÛÒ from the kitchen to the living room, bedroom, home office, and eventhe hall closet. Williams-Sonoma, Pottery Barn, Pottery Barn Kids, PBteen,West Elm, Mark & Graham, and Rejuvenation are the strong, growing brandsthat allow us to reach a diverse customer group throughout different stagesof life.By embracing new technologies and customer-engagement strategies as theyemerge, we are able to continually refine our best-in-class approach tomulti-channel retailing in the three channels we operate: retail, catalogand e-Commerce. We proudly operate more than 600 stores in the UnitedStates, Canada, Puerto Rico, Australia and the United Kingdom, andfranchise our brands to third parties in the Middle East and SoutheastAsia. Our products are available to customers worldwide through catalogs aswell as our e-Commerce sites, which today produce over 50% of our business.INTERNSHIP PROGRAMThe Williams-Sonoma, Inc. internship program provides 3rd yearundergraduate students with the opportunity to demonstrate skills inbusiness acumen, retail management, marketing, and design. In order toprovide you with a truly comprehensive view of our company, we are offeringan internship program to experience both the retail and corporate sides ofour business. The internships available at corporate are in the followingdepartments:‰Û¢             MERCHANDISING‰Û¢             INVENTORY MANAGEMENT‰Û¢             FINANCE‰Û¢             E-COMMERCE‰Û¢             RETAIL OPERATIONS‰Û¢             PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT & VISUAL‰Û¢             INTERNET CREATIVE‰Û¢             MARKETING‰Û¢             PUBLIC RELATIONS‰Û¢             HUMAN RESOURCESRETAIL PORTIONFor one (1) week of your internship, we will place you in one of ourPottery Barn, Pottery Barn Kids, or Williams-Sonoma retail stores in theBay Area. While in the stores, you will work with District and GeneralManagers to learn how a retail store runs and operates, allowing you theopportunity to learn sales, customer service, payroll, live inventory, andhow to manage a team. You will also have the chance to spend time directlywith the customers, seeing firsthand the impact the retail stores have onthe overall success of the business. Learning our retail business providesa strong foundation for the corporate portion of the internship.CORPORATE PORTIONFor the remaining nine (9) weeks of your internship you will be working atour Williams-Sonoma, Inc. Corporate Headquarters in San Francisco. You willbe placed in and matched with a department based on your interviews,interests, and skill set. These departments are Merchandising, InventoryManagement, Sourcing, E-Commerce, Retail Operations, Creative Services, ITand Marketing. During these weeks, you will have theopportunity to attend business critical meetings, assist on projects, andgain experience in cross-functional partnerships.In addition to your daily tasks, you will participate in a group project.The group project will include other cross-functional interns and willrequire each intern to contribute their department knowledge and insightsto deliver an overall business plan. You will also partake in weeklysessions with the other interns, participating in personal and professionaltrainings as well as attending meetings with the executive leaders of thecompany and brands.DURATIONThe nine week program begins on Monday, June 13th and ends on Friday,August 19th.LOCATIONWeek 1‰ÛÒ Orientation at Corporate Headquarters, San Francisco, CA& Retail stores within the Bay AreaWeeks 2-10 ‰ÛÒ Corporate Headquarters, San Francisco, CAQUALIFICATIONS & SKILLS‰Û¢             Junior in an accredited degree program‰Û¢             Strong verbal and written communication skills‰Û¢             Strong analytical skills‰Û¢             Teamwork oriented‰Û¢             Ability to work independently under tight timelines‰Û¢             Ability to prioritize and multi-task‰Û¢             Proficiency in Microsoft Suite and/or MAC OS (depending onthe department)o             Heavy emphasis on Excel for business related functions‰Û¢             Familiarity with the following programs for Creative andDesign internshipso             InDesigno             Photoshopo             Illustratoro             Adobe Social‰Û¢             Ability to work in the San Francisco area for the full tenweek program‰Û¢             Passion for the home industry-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A. | Statistics Minora1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Of course, it helped that I grew up with a>> grandfather, father and uncle who were all in the active practice of law>> (going to court, writing pleadings, etc.); so I had an idea of what it was>> like to be an attorney. Hi Sarita,Thank you for reaching out to me! Hi Tito Reggie!I first wanted to thank you for taking the time to speak to me and my dadabout practicing law. I'm really happy to hear from you again, especiallynow that I'm older and our exchanges can be more meaningful than the shy"hello"s I'd offer as a kid :)As of late, I've been exploring post-grad options and law school is on theradar. I love to read and write; my favorite classes are the ones thatchallenge me to think critically about the texts I read. I like howpracticing law continues to develop these critical reading and writingskills, and I hope to serve the underprivileged with the knowledge andopportunities provided by having a law degree.Aside from this, I know very little about law school and practicing law ingeneral. I'm eager to ask questions and learn more about the field, but I'mhaving trouble finding a place to start.I wanted to know, how did you discover that you wanted to practice law (asopposed to any other similar occupations)? Similarly, how did you know thatthe time and monetary investment of law school was worth it in the end?On a more tangible note, what sorts of skills do law students need tosucceed in that field?No rush on the answers to any of these questions -- my schedule fits aroundyours. If an email exchange is more convenient for you than a phone call,then I'll be happy to do that as well! Thank you again.Best,-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A.a1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

I was very>>> excited to read about the opportunity to work with Ms. Visvanathan and>>> started crafting a letter soon after reading up on the organization. My CV>>> and Cover Letter are attached below :)>>>>>> As far as narrowing my interests, I find myself most passionate about>>> helping children. Volunteering with a local Kindergarten class this past>>> month made me realize how crucial it is that kids, especially really young>>> ones, receive lots of attention and support. As anyone could have guessed,>>> the students that received the most support at home (either in pre-school,>>> daycare, or parental) generally had the most success at school. Having this>>> success gave kids more confidence, encouraged them to take risks, and>>> ultimately lead to healthy scholastic and emotional growth. A young mind>>> really is a tabula rasa, and the more positive influences imparted upon it,>>> the better.>>> Knowing how delicate and absorbent a child's mind can be, I wince at the>>> thought of some students going home to a tumultuous family situation. I>>> began to see the importance of my volunteering opportunity because class>>> was sometimes the greatest amount of attention and care that some students>>> would receive in the day. Being a classroom assistant gave me a small>>> window of opportunity to make a positive impact on these students' lives,>>> whether through teaching them something new, playing with them if they're>>> alone, or just listening to them express their thoughts on their own.>>> I really enjoyed working with children and learning about their growth>>> in an educational setting. I hope I can take this knowledge abroad and work>>> with an NGO that specializes in children's education. Child protection for>>> the abused/for refugees, assisting single mothers, and juvenile justice are>>> also issues that interest me. I am especially drawn to juvenile justice>>> because I am considering a career in law.>>>>>> Working with kids in Malaysia would be a dream. The two weeks I spent in>>> the country were life-changing, and this cliche is not said lightly.>>> Learning about history/politics/economics in a non-Western, non-eurocentric>>> environment drastically opened up the world for me, and I hope to continue>>> this unique education with more exposure to organizations and daily life in>>> South East Asia.>>>>>> Thank you again, and I look forward to hearing from you!>>>>>> Regards,>>> Aida>>>>>>>>-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A.a1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

Hi Daniel,Thank you for responding to my request! I've only considered pre-lawseriously this past winter break, so I'm currently trying to decide whetherit's personally right for me.1) What GPA range is typically considered a competitive GPA for applying tolaw school? I'm pursuing a Statistics minor, and I'm worried that this willnegatively affect my current GPA and make it less competitive comeapplication time.2) What sorts of programs/clubs are available on campus to see if lawschool is something I want to pursue? My family has had nobackground/connections to the field of law whatsoever, so I feel a bit lostabout what I'm about to head into. I do want to strengthen my reading,writing, and critical thinking skills past my bachelor's degree, and Ifigured that the knowledge picked up in law school will be useful in manycareers (I don't know what I want to do yet), so I'm currently exploringthe pre-law option.3) What sorts of skills (besides critical thinking, reading and writing)are necessary to be successful in law school?Thank you for your help! I really appreciate it.Aida Ylanan-- *Aida Avelina Ylanan*University of California, Los Angeles | Class of 2018Political Science B.A.a1daylanan@ucla.edu | (562) 673-1996

---------- Forwarded message ----------From: Nazneen Agha <nazneen_agha@yahoo.co.uk>Date: Thu, Sep 3, 2015 at 10:05 PMSubject: Re: Meeting Follow-UpTo: AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu>Cc: Sharifah Agha <sharifahnaz@gmail.com>Hi Aida,Lovely to hear from you and apologies for this very late reply - I had somebusy weeks though I did mean to reply much earlier! I hope you had awonderful stay in Malaysia. I am very glad to know that you are nowconsidering active involvement in non-profits!(Also - I am copying my gmail address as I am trying to now migrate fromthis ancient yahoo address so do use that one in the future! thanks).I could definitely assist with internships in Malaysia. For UN internshipsin Geneva or New York for example, there is a set procedure which you caneasily follow from their websites, as I don't have any direct contacts forthis.I would suggest you start your internship with an NGO in Malaysia, givenalso the presence of family this helps a lot for your first experience. Irecommend working with my good friend and ex-mentor Sumitra Visvanathan whoheads the Women's Aid Organization (WAO) a leading NGO in Malaysia focusedon domestic violence for women and children. WAO has a very establishedadvocacy platform in addiiton to their core service of running shelters(you can check out their website for more info).Sumitra also has 15 years of experience working with the UNHCR, and she isa particularly dynamic individual you will enjoy working with. I referredanother sophomore student from Wharton recently to her, and this was a verygood exchange for both.I would also suggest that you try and narrow your area of interest inworking with NGOs - eg are you keen on issues related to women? refugees?migrants? child protection for the sexually abused? the environment? artsand heritage? access to education? juvenile justice?  This will make iteasier for you to know which organizations you should apply to. I shouldalso say there are fabulous NGOs in the US which you should also consideran internship with.So let's start with that - if you like, we can have a quick chat over Skypeto help you narrow your interest areas or if you know this already then dosend me your thoughts (at the gmail account) and let me know why you areinterested in it - articulating your passion helps to focus your thoughts!I am also available on facebook under Sharifah Nazneen - and can forwardyou stuff suited to your interests as and when I receive it.For Sumitra/WAO, if you send me your cv as well as a cover note statingyour interest to be an intern with WAO I can forward this to her and youcan start communicating directly with her on a potential internship.regards,Nazneen--------------------------------------------On Wed, 26/8/15, AIDA AVELINA YLANAN <a1daylanan@ucla.edu> wrote: Subject: Meeting Follow-Up To: nazneen_agha@yahoo.co.uk Date: Wednesday, 26 August, 2015, 8:09 Hello Ms. Agha, My name is Aida Ylanan, and I wanted to take the opportunity to thank you again for meeting with me and my aunt and uncle (Mr. and Mrs. Ghazzali) at the Hilton Hotel in KL two weeks ago.
